content.title: Respiratory Acidosis
content.summary: Primary acid-base disorder characterized by elevated PaCO2 (>45 mmHg) due to alveolar hypoventilation, with compensatory renal bicarbonate retention
key_points: Defined by PaCO2 >45 mmHg with decreased pH
Caused by alveolar hypoventilation (COPD, CNS depression, neuromuscular disease)
Acute: pH drops 0.08 for each 10 mmHg rise in PaCO2
Chronic: pH drops 0.03 for each 10 mmHg rise in PaCO2 (renal compensation)
Renal compensation takes 3-5 days to fully develop
Treatment: address underlying cause, improve ventilation
Caution: rapid PaCO2 correction can cause posthypercapnic alkalosis

statement.text: Respiratory acidosis is a primary acid-base disturbance caused by alveolar hypoventilation leading to CO2 retention (PaCO2 >45 mmHg). The elevated CO2 shifts the bicarbonate buffer system toward hydrogen ion generation, decreasing pH. In acute respiratory acidosis, buffering is limited; in chronic respiratory acidosis, the kidney compensates by retaining bicarbonate, partially normalizing pH but not returning it to normal.
statement.formal: Respiratory Acidosis = PaCO2 >45 mmHg + ↓pH; Acute: ΔpH = -0.08 per 10 mmHg ↑PaCO2; Chronic: ΔpH = -0.03 per 10 mmHg ↑PaCO2

explanation.intuition: CO2 is an acid when dissolved in water (forms carbonic acid). When ventilation is inadequate, CO2 builds up in the blood like exhaust fumes in a poorly ventilated room. The body tries to compensate by having the kidneys hold onto bicarbonate (the base), but this takes days. In the meantime, the blood becomes dangerously acidic.
explanation.key_insight: The pH tells you acuity: acute respiratory acidosis causes a larger pH drop per unit CO2 increase than chronic. If the pH is near normal despite high CO2, expect chronic compensation. If pH is severely low with high CO2, it's either acute or acute-on-chronic.
explanation.technical_details: Henderson-Hasselbalch: pH = 6.1 + log([HCO3-] / (0.03 × PaCO2)). As PaCO2 rises, the ratio decreases, lowering pH. Renal compensation: increased H+ excretion and HCO3- reabsorption in the proximal tubule; enhanced ammonia synthesis for H+ buffering. Compensation formula: Expected HCO3- = 24 + (ΔPaCO2 × 0.1) for acute; 24 + (ΔPaCO2 × 0.4) for chronic.

definitions_glossary.respiratory_acidosis: Primary acid-base disorder with elevated PaCO2 due to hypoventilation
definitions_glossary.hypercapnia: Elevated arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2 >45 mmHg)
definitions_glossary.hypoventilation: Inadequate alveolar ventilation relative to CO2 production
definitions_glossary.paco2: Partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood
definitions_glossary.acute_respiratory_acidosis: Sudden onset hypercapnia without renal compensation
definitions_glossary.chronic_respiratory_acidosis: Sustained hypercapnia with renal bicarbonate retention
definitions_glossary.renal_compensation: Kidney's adaptive response to acid-base disturbances by adjusting bicarbonate handling
definitions_glossary.carbonic_anhydrase: Enzyme catalyzing CO2 hydration to carbonic acid in kidneys and red blood cells
definitions_glossary.posthypercapnic_alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis after rapid correction of chronic hypercapnia
definitions_glossary.co2_narcosis: Altered consciousness from severe hypercapnia (typically PaCO2 >70-80 mmHg)
definitions_glossary.minute_ventilation: Total volume of air breathed per minute (tidal volume × respiratory rate)
definitions_glossary.dead_space: Portion of each breath that does not participate in gas exchange

pathophysiology.mechanism: Alveolar hypoventilation reduces CO2 elimination, causing PaCO2 to rise. CO2 combines with water (via carbonic anhydrase) to form carbonic acid (H2CO3), which dissociates into H+ and HCO3-. The increased H+ lowers blood pH. In acute respiratory acidosis, buffering capacity is limited to non-bicarbonate buffers (hemoglobin, proteins). In chronic respiratory acidosis, the kidneys compensate by increasing H+ excretion and HCO3- reabsorption, raising serum bicarbonate.

clinical_manifestations.neurologic: Anxiety, confusion, somnolence, CO2 narcosis (coma), asterixis, papilledema
clinical_manifestations.respiratory: Dyspnea, use of accessory muscles, decreased respiratory effort

arterial_blood_gas.ph: <7.35 (may be near normal in chronic with compensation)

compensation_assessment.acute: Expected HCO3- = 24 + (ΔPaCO2 × 0.1); Expected pH drop = 0.08 per 10 mmHg ↑PaCO2
compensation_assessment.chronic: Expected HCO3- = 24 + (ΔPaCO2 × 0.4); Expected pH drop = 0.03 per 10 mmHg ↑PaCO2
compensation_assessment.interpretation: If HCO3- higher than expected for acute, it's chronic or metabolic alkalosis coexists

additional_workup: Pulse oximetry and assessment of hypoxemia
Chest X-ray for underlying lung disease

general_principles.goal: Improve alveolar ventilation to lower PaCO2
general_principles.caution: In chronic hypercapnia, avoid rapid correction—posthypercapnic alkalosis can cause seizures, arrhythmias
general_principles.target: Aim for patient's baseline PaCO2, not normal (40 mmHg)

non_invasive_ventilation.indication: Moderate respiratory acidosis (pH 7.25-7.35), alert patient, can protect airway
non_invasive_ventilation.mechanism: Inspiratory pressure assists ventilation; expiratory pressure maintains alveolar recruitment

invasive_ventilation.indication: Severe respiratory acidosis (pH <7.25), altered mental status, hemodynamic instability
invasive_ventilation.settings: Increase minute ventilation (↑RR or ↑TV) to reduce PaCO2

monitoring.abg: Serial ABGs to monitor response and avoid overcorrection
monitoring.clinical: Mental status, respiratory effort, vital signs

definition.@value: Primary acid-base disorder characterized by elevated PaCO2 (>45 mmHg) due to alveolar hypoventilation, causing decreased blood pH

skos.scopeNote: Covers acute and chronic forms, etiologies, compensation mechanisms, and treatment strategies
skos.example: A 65-year-old with severe COPD presenting with confusion, ABG showing pH 7.28, PaCO2 68 mmHg, HCO3- 32 mEq/L, consistent with acute-on-chronic respiratory acidosis

learning_objectives: Define respiratory acidosis and differentiate acute from chronic forms
Apply compensation formulas to interpret arterial blood gases
Identify common causes of respiratory acidosis
Select appropriate ventilatory support based on severity
clinical_pearls: COPD patients: don't 'normalize' PaCO2—target their baseline (often 50-60 mmHg)
Acute-on-chronic: pH more acidotic than expected for the degree of HCO3- elevation
BiPAP can avoid intubation in COPD exacerbations—try early if patient is cooperative
Posthypercapnic alkalosis: when chronic CO2 retainers are 'fixed' rapidly, HCO3- remains high
Asterixis in respiratory acidosis: CO2 narcosis affecting neuromuscular function
Suspect opioid overdose if respiratory rate <12 with pinpoint pupils

board_yield.pulmonology_boards: Very High - ventilator management, BiPAP indications

common_misconceptions: Normal pH with high PaCO2 is 'fully compensated' (false—metabolic component should also be considered)
Oxygen is contraindicated in all COPD patients (false—give O2, monitor for worsening hypercapnia)
Rapid correction of chronic hypercapnia is safe (false—posthypercapnic alkalosis is dangerous)
